abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was
            satisfactory, sustainability is likely, and the
            institutional development impact is substantial. Lessons
            suggest that the slow process of reforming institutional
            structure, and management approaches, requires a sustained
            dialogue beyond one operation's scope, in addition to a
            continuous monitoring, and supportive policy advice to the
            reform program. Based on the recent institutional
            development, and weak capacity at the project's
            preparation, more than one operation will be required to set
            a sustainable transport sector in Mozambique. Government
            ownership is a crucial factor for project success,
            exemplified in this project, particularly, by the competent
            management of the National Directorate of Roads and Bridges,
            who developed a system of technical assistance monitoring,
            and evaluation, thus ensuring the capacity of local staff,
            and, strengthened human resources, by adapting their
            capacity to the local needs, and environment. However, there
            is still a need to address comprehensive road policy
            reforms, ensuring all sector aspects, that is, provision of
            adequate financing for road maintenance, and management
            arrangements, and, most importantly, ensure a political
            commitment to safeguard the use of money, and a
            check-and-balance governance system, to restrict
            government's discretionary power, and arbitrary behavior.
